document.title: Fatou’s theorem, Bergman spaces, and Hardy spaces on the circle

para.p: In this note I am writing out proofs of some facts about Fourier series, Bergman spaces, and Hardy spaces. §§1–3 follow the presentation in Stein and Shakarchi’s Real Analysis and Fourier Analysis. The questions in Halmos’s Hilbert Space Problem Book that deal with Hardy spaces are: §§24–35, 67, 116–117, 124–125, 127, 193–199, and I present solutions to some of these in §§4–5, on Bergman spaces, and §6, on Hardy spaces.

Let
= T
⁢
/ R 2
π Z
. Let

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ (L ^ p) = ((1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((absolute-value@(f * t)) ^ p * differential-d@(t))) ^ (1 / p)

para.p:
If
∈ f
⁢
L 1
( T )
, let

Math.text: hat@(f) * k = (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * e ^ (- i * k * t) * differential-d@(t))

para.p: Define

Math.text: formulae@(P _ r * t = (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * e ^ (i * n * t)) = (1 - r ^ 2) / ((1 - 2 * r * cosine@(t)) + r ^ 2), 0 less= r less 1, t element-of T)

para.p:
One checks that
P r
is an approximation to the identity, which implies that for
∈ f
⁢
L 1
( T )
, for almost all
∈ θ T
we have
→
⁢

as

1 -
. 1 1 footnote 1 If
f
is continuous, then

P r
converges to
f
uniformly on
T
as
→ r
1 -
. This is proved for example in Lang’s Complex Analysis, fourth ed., chapter VIII, §5.

For
∈ f
⁢
L 1
( T )
, for any
θ
we have

Math.text: (norm@(f * t * (sum _ (absolute-value@(n) less= N))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * e ^ (i * n * (theta - t))))) _ (L ^ 1) less= ((1 + r) / (1 - r)) * (norm@(f)) _ (L ^ 1)

para.p: hence by the dominated convergence theorem we have

Math.text: (limit _ (N to infinity))@((sum _ (absolute-value@(n) less= N))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * e ^ (i * n * (theta - t)) * differential-d@(t)))) = (limit _ (N to infinity))@(((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * (sum _ (absolute-value@(n) less= N))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * e ^ (i * n * (theta - t)) * d * t))) = ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * e ^ (i * n * (theta - t)) * d * t))
(limit _ (N to infinity))@((sum _ (absolute-value@(n) less= N))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * e ^ (i * n * (theta - t)) * differential-d@(t))))
(limit _ (N to infinity))@(((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * (sum _ (absolute-value@(n) less= N))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * e ^ (i * n * (theta - t)) * d * t)))
((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * e ^ (i * n * (theta - t)) * d * t))

para.p: and so

Math.text: f * P _ r * theta = (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * P _ r * (theta - t) * differential-d@(t)) = (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * e ^ (i * n * (theta - t)) * d * t)) = (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * e ^ (i * n * (theta - t)) * differential-d@(t))) = (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * e ^ (i * n * theta) * hat@(f) * n)
f * P _ r * theta
(1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * P _ r * (theta - t) * differential-d@(t))
(1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * e ^ (i * n * (theta - t)) * d * t))
(sum _ (n element-of Z))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * e ^ (i * n * (theta - t)) * differential-d@(t)))
(sum _ (n element-of Z))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * e ^ (i * n * theta) * hat@(f) * n)

para.p:
For
∈ f
⁢
L 1
( T )
, define
u f
on
<
| z |
1
by

Math.text: u _ f * r * e ^ (i * theta) = f * P _ r * theta

para.p: In polar coordinates, the Laplacian is

Math.text: Delta = partial-differential ^ 2 / partial-differential@(r ^ 2) + (1 / r) * (partial-differential / partial-differential@(r)) + (1 / r ^ 2) * (partial-differential ^ 2 / partial-differential@(theta ^ 2))

para.p: Then

Math.text: Delta * u _ f * r * e ^ (i * theta) = Delta * ((sum _ (n less 0))@(r ^ (- n) * e ^ (i * n * theta) * hat@(f) * n) + (sum _ (n >= 0))@(r ^ n * e ^ (i * n * theta) * hat@(f) * n)) = (sum _ (n less 0))@(hat@(f) * n * Delta * r ^ (- n) * e ^ (i * n * theta)) + (sum _ (n >= 0))@(hat@(f) * n * Delta * r ^ n * e ^ (i * n * theta)) = (sum _ (n less 0))@((hat@(f) * n) cdot 0) + (sum _ (n >= 0))@((hat@(f) * n) cdot 0) = 0
Delta * u _ f * r * e ^ (i * theta)
Delta * ((sum _ (n less 0))@(r ^ (- n) * e ^ (i * n * theta) * hat@(f) * n) + (sum _ (n >= 0))@(r ^ n * e ^ (i * n * theta) * hat@(f) * n))
(sum _ (n less 0))@(hat@(f) * n * Delta * r ^ (- n) * e ^ (i * n * theta)) + (sum _ (n >= 0))@(hat@(f) * n * Delta * r ^ n * e ^ (i * n * theta))
(sum _ (n less 0))@((hat@(f) * n) cdot 0) + (sum _ (n >= 0))@((hat@(f) * n) cdot 0)

para.p:
Hence
u f
is harmonic on the open unit disc.

Math.text: formulae@(F * z = (sum _ (n >= 0))@(a _ n * z ^ n), a _ n element-of C)

para.p:
By the Cauchy integral formula, for
≥ n 0

F ^ n * 0
(nfactorial / (2 * pi * i)) * (integral _ gamma _ r)@(((F * zeta) / zeta ^ (n + 1)) * differential-d@(zeta))
(nfactorial / (2 * pi * i)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(((F * r * e ^ (i * theta)) / (r * e ^ (i * theta)) ^ (n + 1)) * r * i * e ^ (i * theta) * differential-d@(theta))
(nfactorial / (2 * pi * r ^ n)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(F * r * e ^ (i * theta) * e ^ (- i * n * theta) * differential-d@(theta))

Hence, for

para.p:
On the other hand, for
< n 0
, we have

Math.text: (nfactorial / (2 * pi * r ^ n)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(F * r * e ^ (i * theta) * e ^ (- i * n * theta) * differential-d@(theta)) = (nfactorial / (2 * pi * i)) * (integral _ gamma _ r)@(((F * zeta) / zeta ^ (n + 1)) * differential-d@(zeta))

para.p:
and because
⁢ F

para.p:
As
∈ f
⁢

( T )

∈ f
⁢
L 1
( T )
. Then by our work in §, for almost all
∈ θ T
we have

Math.text: (limit _ (r to 1 ^ -))@((sum _ (n element-of Z))@(r ^ (absolute-value@(n)) * e ^ (i * n * theta) * hat@(f) * n)) = f * theta

para.p:
which means here that for almost all
∈ θ T
,

Math.text: (limit _ (r to 1 ^ -))@((sum _ (n >= 0))@(a _ n * r ^ n * e ^ (i * n * theta))) = f * theta

para.p:
Thus, for almost all
∈ θ T
,

Math.text: (limit _ (r to 1 ^ -))@(F * r * e ^ (i * theta)) = f * theta

para.p:
In words, we have proved that if
F
is a bounded holomorphic function on the unit disc, then it has radial limits at almost every angle. This is Fatou’s theorem.

If
U
is a nonempty bounded open subset of
C

1 ≤ p < ∞

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ (A ^ p * U) = ((integral _ U)@((absolute-value@(f * z)) ^ p * differential-d@(mu) * z)) ^ (1 / p) less infinity

and let

para.p:
It is apparent that
⁢

C

∥ ⋅
∥
⁢

( U )
is a norm, and thus
⁢
A p
( U )
is a normed space. If
≤ p q
then by Jensen’s inequality we have

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ (A ^ p * U) less= mu * D ^ (1 / p - 1 / q) * (norm@(f)) _ (A ^ q * U)

para.p: and so

Math.text: A ^ q * U subset-of-or-equals A ^ p * U

para.p:
⁢
A p
( U )
is called a Bergman space. It is not apparent that it is a complete metric space. We show this using the following lemmas. We use the following lemma to prove the lemma after it, and use that lemma to prove the theorem.

Math.text: (integral _ (D * open-interval@(z _ 0, r)))@(f * z * differential-d@(mu) * z) = (limit _ (n to infinity))@((integral _ (D * open-interval@(z _ 0, r)))@(F _ n * z * differential-d@(mu) * z)) = (limit _ (n to infinity))@((integral _ (D * open-interval@(z _ 0, r)))@(((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(a _ k * (z - z _ 0) ^ k * d * mu * z))) = (limit _ (n to infinity))@(((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(a _ k * (integral _ (D * open-interval@(z _ 0, r)))@((z - z _ 0) ^ k * differential-d@(mu) * z))) = (limit _ (n to infinity))@(((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(a _ k * (integral _ (D * open-interval@(0, r)))@(z ^ k * differential-d@(mu) * z)))

para.p:
For
≥ k 1
, using polar coordinates we have

Math.text: (integral _ (D * open-interval@(0, r)))@(z ^ k * differential-d@(mu) * z) = ((integral _ 0) ^ r)@(((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((rho * e ^ (i * theta)) ^ k * rho * differential-d@(theta) * differential-d@(rho))) = ((integral _ 0) ^ r)@(((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(rho ^ (k + 1) * e ^ (i * k * theta) * differential-d@(theta) * differential-d@(rho))) = ((integral _ 0) ^ r)@((rho ^ (k + 1) cdot (0 / k)) * differential-d@(rho)) = 0
(integral _ (D * open-interval@(0, r)))@(z ^ k * differential-d@(mu) * z)
((integral _ 0) ^ r)@(((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((rho * e ^ (i * theta)) ^ k * rho * differential-d@(theta) * differential-d@(rho)))
((integral _ 0) ^ r)@(((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(rho ^ (k + 1) * e ^ (i * k * theta) * differential-d@(theta) * differential-d@(rho)))
((integral _ 0) ^ r)@((rho ^ (k + 1) cdot (0 / k)) * differential-d@(rho))

Math.text: (integral _ (D * open-interval@(z _ 0, r)))@(f * z * differential-d@(mu) * z) = (limit _ (n to infinity))@((a _ 0 cdot pi) * r ^ 2) = (a _ 0 cdot pi) * r ^ 2
(integral _ (D * open-interval@(z _ 0, r)))@(f * z * differential-d@(mu) * z)
(limit _ (n to infinity))@((a _ 0 cdot pi) * r ^ 2)
(a _ 0 cdot pi) * r ^ 2

That is, for each
0 < r < R
we have

Now we prove that

is a complete metric space, showing that it is a Banach space.

Math.tex: \displaystyle\left\langle v,e_{n}\right\rangle=\left\langle\mathrm{Im}\,Du,e_{% n}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2i}\left(\left\langle Du,e_{n}\right\rangle-\overline% {\left\langle Du,e_{-n}\right\rangle}\right)=\begin{cases}0&n=0\\ \frac{1}{2i}\left(\left\langle u,e_{n}\right\rangle+\overline{\left\langle u,e% _{-n}\right\rangle}\right)&n>0\\ -\frac{1}{2i}\overline{\left(\left\langle u,e_{-n}\right\rangle+\overline{% \left\langle u,e_{n}\right\rangle}\right)}&n<0\end{cases}=\begin{cases}0&n=0\\ \frac{1}{2i}\left(\left\langle u,e_{n}\right\rangle+\overline{\left\langle u,e% _{-n}\right\rangle}\right)&n>0\\ -\frac{1}{2i}\left(\left\langle u,e_{n}\right\rangle+\overline{\left\langle u,% e_{-n}\right\rangle}\right)&n<0\end{cases}=\begin{cases}0&n=0\\ \frac{1}{i}\left\langle u,e_{n}\right\rangle&n>0\\ -\frac{1}{i}\left\langle u,e_{n}\right\rangle&n<0.\end{cases}
Math.text: list@(v, e _ n) = list@(Im * D * u, e _ n) = (1 / (2 * i)) * (list@(D * u, e _ n) - overline@(list@(D * u, e _ (- n)))) = cases@(0, n = 0, (1 / (2 * i)) * (list@(u, e _ n) + overline@(list@(u, e _ (- n)))), n > 0, - (1 / (2 * i)) * overline@(list@(u, e _ (- n)) + overline@(list@(u, e _ n))), n less 0) = cases@(0, n = 0, (1 / (2 * i)) * (list@(u, e _ n) + overline@(list@(u, e _ (- n)))), n > 0, - (1 / (2 * i)) * (list@(u, e _ n) + overline@(list@(u, e _ (- n)))), n less 0) = cases@(0, n = 0, (1 / i) * list@(u, e _ n), n > 0, - (1 / i) * list@(u, e _ n), n less 0)
list@(v, e _ n)
list@(Im * D * u, e _ n)

Math.tex: \displaystyle\left\langle D\mathrm{Re}\,f,e_{n}\right\rangle=\begin{cases}% \frac{\left\langle f,e_{0}\right\rangle+\overline{\left\langle f,e_{0}\right% \rangle}}{2}&n=0\\ \frac{\left\langle f,e_{n}\right\rangle+\overline{\left\langle f,e_{-n}\right% \rangle}}{2}+\frac{\overline{\left\langle f,e_{-n}\right\rangle}+\left\langle f% ,e_{n}\right\rangle}{2}&n>0\\ 0&n<0.\end{cases}=\begin{cases}\frac{\left\langle f,e_{0}\right\rangle+% \overline{\left\langle f,e_{0}\right\rangle}}{2}&n=0\\ \left\langle f,e_{n}\right\rangle&n>0\\ 0&n<0\end{cases}=\begin{cases}\frac{\left\langle f,e_{0}\right\rangle+% \overline{\left\langle f,e_{0}\right\rangle}}{2}&n=0\\ \left\langle f,e_{n}\right\rangle&n\neq 0\end{cases}
Math.text: list@(D * Re * f, e _ n) = cases@((list@(f, e _ 0) + overline@(list@(f, e _ 0))) / 2, n = 0, (list@(f, e _ n) + overline@(list@(f, e _ (- n)))) / 2 + (overline@(list@(f, e _ (- n))) + list@(f, e _ n)) / 2, n > 0, 0, n less 0) = cases@((list@(f, e _ 0) + overline@(list@(f, e _ 0))) / 2, n = 0, list@(f, e _ n), n > 0, 0, n less 0) = cases@((list@(f, e _ 0) + overline@(list@(f, e _ 0))) / 2, n = 0, list@(f, e _ n), n not-equals 0)
list@(D * Re * f, e _ n)
cases@((list@(f, e _ 0) + overline@(list@(f, e _ 0))) / 2, n = 0, (list@(f, e _ n) + overline@(list@(f, e _ (- n)))) / 2 + (overline@(list@(f, e _ (- n))) + list@(f, e _ n)) / 2, n > 0, 0, n less 0)
cases@((list@(f, e _ 0) + overline@(list@(f, e _ 0))) / 2, n = 0, list@(f, e _ n), n > 0, 0, n less 0)
cases@((list@(f, e _ 0) + overline@(list@(f, e _ 0))) / 2, n = 0, list@(f, e _ n), n not-equals 0)

para.p: Thus

Math.text: list@(f - D * Re * f, e _ n) = cases@((list@(f, e _ 0) - overline@(list@(f, e _ 0))) / 2, n = 0, 0, n not-equals 0) = cases@(i cdot list@(Im * f, e _ 0), n = 0, 0, n not-equals 0)
